Abortion is not a dirty word. 

Abortion care is healthcare.

The rights enshrined in Roe are crucial, and I will not stop fighting until legal and safe abortions are the law of the land in all 50 states again.

(7/7)

Life under Roe meant confidence in authority over your own body.

Confidence that if, tragically, something happened to your baby, your family wouldn't lose both of you.

Confidence that your medical decisions are *your* business ‚Äî between you and your doctor.

(6/7)

Right-wing extremists would like you to think that life under Roe was lawlessness ‚Äî "abortion on demand" or "abortion right up until the moment of birth."

That is simply not true.

(5/7)

Eight years before Roe, illegal abortion¬†caused 17 percent of pregnancy-related deaths.

Now, less than half of one percent of people who have abortions even require hospitalization for complications.

(4/7)

Abortion could still be banned in the third trimester ‚Äî but only if there were exceptions where abortion was necessary to save the life or health of the mother.

Today, under Dobbs, abortion bans are not required to make any exceptions ‚Äî even to save a mother's life.

(3/7)

Roe v. Wade was decided on January 22nd, 1973.

In a 7-2 decision, the majority decided that the state's interest in the ‚Äúpotentiality of human life,‚Äù varies depending on the stage of pregnancy, and the law must reflect that.

(2/7)

Today would've been 51 years since Roe v. Wade.

We've also now endured more than 50 years of misinformation about Roe and abortion.

So let's set the record straight. On this day in 1973, Garrick Utley of NBC put it simply:

Our third place winner is a grocery-tracking app called Waste Watcher designed by Hazen High School students Elizabeth Nguyen and Aiden Yav. Waste Watcher allows users to track food and expiration dates, helping users develop more sustainable eating habits with less food waste.

Our second place winner is a transit app called Commuter, created by Interlake High School students Piyush Acharya, Nishant Vikramaditya, and Aarnav Bhat. This app promotes sustainable transportation with a leaderboard where users compete to see who can save the most CO2.

Our first place winner is a data privacy app called Volapyk,  designed by Mercer Island High School students Davin Aoyama and Abhay Raj. Volapyk uses machine learning technologies to score privacy policies and terms of service on how they protect or infringe on privacy.
